"Sado" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 803. ==History== Uesugi Kagekatsu took control of the island in the late 1580s.Goldsmith, Brian (2008). Amassing Economies: The Medieval Origins of Early Modern Japan, 1450--1700, p. 249; Nussbaum, "Uesugi Kagekatsu" at p. 1009. In the Edo period, gold was discovered on the island. The Tokugawa shogunate took direct control of it. It was administered by an official called the Sado-bugyō for gold mining. Okubo Nagayasu was appointed to this position by Tokugawa Ieyasu in 1603.Nussbaum, "Okubo Nagayasu" at p. 747. In the Meiji period, the island became part of Niigata Prefecture. ==References== ==Related pages== *Watatsu Shrine ==Other websites== *Sado Tourism Association English language site *Sado City website *Sado Island at JNTO.go.jp Category:Cities in Niigata Prefecture Category:World Heritage Sites in Japan
